facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2180 of 1970 filed by the appellant (tenant) by special leave from Madhya Pradesh High Court judgment dated 14th August 1970 in Second Appeal No. 48 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2180 of 1970. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 14th August, 1970 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court at Gwalior in Second Appeal No. 48 of 1, 69.

facts.text: Respondent owns a house in Lohia Bazar, Gwalior, consisting of a shop on ground floor and residential accommodation on first floor.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is the owner of a house situate in Lohia Bazar in the city of Gwalior. The house companysists of a shop on the ground floor and residential accommodation on the first floor.

facts.text: Appellant has been tenant of the Lohia Bazar shop for about thirty years, carrying on business as dealer in iron and steel materials.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is in occupation of the residential accommodation on the first floor since the past few years. The ground floor shop, which may hereinafter for the sake of companyvenience be referred to as the Lohia Bazar shop, has been in the possession of the appellant as a tenant for the last about thirty years.

facts.text: Rent of Lohia Bazar shop originally Rs. 8 per month, increased to Rs. 25 per month in 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant carries on business as a dealer in iron and steel materials in this shop. Originally the rent of this shop was Rs. 8/- per month but it was subsequently increased from time to time and ultimately in 1946 it was fixed at Rs. 25/- per month.

facts.text: First suit for eviction filed by respondent towards end of 1952, decree by Trial Court reversed by Additional District Judge on 8th December 1956 under Madhya Bharat Premises Restriction Act, Sy. 2006.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that towards the end of 1952 the respondent decided to evict the appellant from the Lohia Bazar shop and with that end in view, filed a suit for recovery of possession of Lohia Bazar shop. ... his suit was accordingly dismissed by the Additional District Judge on 8th December, 1956.

facts.text: Second suit filed by respondent within few months after first dismissal, amended in March 1959, dismissed by Additional District Judge on 4th August 1962 under Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Within a few months after the dismissal of this suit, however, the respondent, undaunted by this reverse, filed another suit against the appellant for recovering possession of the Lohia Bazar shop. ... The Additional District Judge accordingly dismissed the suit by a judgment dated 4th August, 1962.

facts.text: Lease deed dated 15th September 1962 between respondent and appellant for Lohia Bazar shop for two years at Rs. 60 per month.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the respondent, having failed in both his attempts to recover possession of the Lohia Bazar shop from the appellant, entered into a lease deed dated 15th September, 1962 with the appellant by which he gave a lease of the Lohia Bazar shop to the appellant for a period of two years with effect from 15th September, 1962 at the rent of Rs. 60/- per month.

facts.text: Lease expired on 15th September 1964, appellant continued as monthly tenant at Rs. 60 per month.

anchor.surface_text: Though the period of the lease expired on 15th September, 1964, the appellant companytinued in posses- sion of the Lohia Bazar shop as a monthly tenant of the respondent paying the same rent of Rs. 60/- per month.

facts.text: Respondent surrendered Phalke Bazar shop in 1964 and closed grocery business, no other occupation after.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that some time in 1964-the exact date does number appear from the record-the respondent voluntarily surrendered possession of the Phalke Bazar shop to the landlord and closed down his grocery business.

facts.text: Appellant alleged respondent surrendered Phalke Bazar shop for premium, but not established by Trial Court or First Appellate Court.

anchor.surface_text: The ap- pellant alleged that the, respondent gave up possession of the, Phalke, Bazar shop to the, landlord in companysideration of receipt of premium in cash but this allegation was held number established both by the Trial Court as also by the First Appellate Court.

facts.text: Third suit filed by respondent on 17th August 1966 for eviction on ground of bona fide requirement for iron and steel business under MP Accommodation Control Act 1961.

anchor.surface_text: On 17th August, 1966, after a period of inaction of about two years, the respondent renewed the fight against the appellant with added vigour and plunged into the turbulent waters of litigation by filing a third suit to recover possession of the Lohia Bazar shop from the appellant.

facts.text: Trial Court in third suit passed decree for eviction, finding respondent bona fide required shop for iron and steel business, no other shop.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court on a companysideration of the evidence led on behalf of both the parties came to the companyclusion that the respondent was without any occupation since about two years prior to the filing of the suit and he had numberother shop in the city in which he companyld carry on business and he, therefore, bona fide required the Lohia Bazar shop for starting his own business as a dealer in iron and steel materials.

facts.text: Additional District Judge reversed Trial Court decree, dismissed suit, finding no bona fide requirement as new business without preparations.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional District Judge on an appreciation of the evidence came to the following findings. ... The Additional District Judge accordingly set aside the decree for eviction passed against the appellant and dismissed the suit of the respondent.

facts.text: High Court in second appeal set aside Additional District Judge judgment, restored Trial Court eviction decree.

anchor.surface_text: On this view the High Court reversed the judgmentof the Additional District Judge and restored the decree for eviction passed by the Trial Court.

facts.text: Respondent about 63 years old when filed third suit.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was about 63 years of age when he filed the suit

facts.text: Respondent previously carried grocery business in Phalke Bazar shop rented from Vishwanath.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the respondent was throughout this period carrying on business as a grocer in a shop situate in Phalke Bazar which was taken by him on rent from one Vishwanath.

facts.text: Appellant disputed respondent's bona fide requirement for Lohia Bazar shop, alleged other accommodation and commission agent/moneylender business.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant disputed that the respondent required the Lohia Bazar shop for starting his own business or that his requirement was bona fide and alleged that in any event the respondent had other accommodation in the city

facts.text: Trial Court rejected appellant's plea that respondent was commission agent and moneylender.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court negatived the plea of the appellant that the respondent was carrying on business as companymission agent and moneylender

facts.text: Additional District Judge found respondent had no experience in iron and steel business, no preparations like capital or permits.

anchor.surface_text: Though it was stated by the respondent in his evidence that he had in the past carried on business as a dealer in iron and steel materials, that was companytradicted by his own witness Chotelal ... There was numbermaterial on record to establish that the respondent had made preparations

facts.text: Supreme Court held finding of no bona fide requirement by Additional District Judge is finding of fact, not interfered by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the finding of the Additional District Judge that the respondent did number bona fide require the Lohia Bazar shop for the purpose of starting business as a. dealer in iron and steel materials was a finding of fact and number a finding of mixed law and fact

facts.text: High Court relied on respondent's unchallenged statement and prior claim in 1959 for iron steel business.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court observed that when the respondent stated in his evidence that he required the Lohia Bazar shop for the purpose of starting business as a dealer in iron and steel materials, there was numbercross-examination ... the respondent had as far back as March 1959 sought to recover possession

facts.text: Respondent without occupation for two years before third suit.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent was without any occupation since about two years prior to the filing of the suit

facts.text: No other shop available to respondent in the city.

anchor.surface_text: since he had admittedly numberother shop inthe city. he was entitled to recover possession

facts.text: Supreme Court found evidence supports Additional District Judge's finding of no bona fide need, including delay after lease expiry and lack of experience.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that here there was evidence to sustain the finding of fact arrived at by the Additional District Judge. The respondent had been trying to obtain possession of the Lohia Bazar shop from the appellant since as far back as 1952

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second appeal jurisdiction limited to substantial question of law; cannot reappreciate evidence or reverse findings of fact unless error of law, no evidence, or perverse.

holdings.text: There were no proper grounds for the High Court to interfere with the finding of fact that respondent did not bona fide require the shop.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No mistake of law, supported by evidence (delay, lack of experience, repeated attempts); irrelevant factors do not vitiate as other evidence sustains.

holdings.text: The respondent did not bona fide require the Lohia Bazar shop under section 12(1)(f) of the MP Accommodation Control Act, 1961, as found by the Additional District Judge.

holdings.text: A larger Bench decision prevails over a smaller Bench decision of the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: we must prefer to follow the decision in Sarvate T.B.s case as against the decision in Smt. Kamla Sonis case as the former is a decision of a larger Bench than the latter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hierarchical precedent rule; Sarvate T.B. (4 judges) over Kamla Soni (3 judges) on whether bona fide requirement is pure fact.

holdings.text: Mere assertion of need is insufficient to prove bona fide requirement; objective test applies, burden on landlord.

precedents.cited_proposition: Finding that landlord does not bona fide require premises is a pure finding of fact which High Court cannot interfere with in second appeal unless vitiated by error of law, no evidence, or perverse
precedents.cited_holding: The District Court considered the evidence for the purpose of ascertaining whether the respondent honestly or in good faith required the premises and held that the respondent failed to establish the case pleaded by him. This finding of the District Court was based on appreciation of evidence and was binding upon the High Court and the High Court had numberpower to reverse that finding.

anchor.surface_text: The main ground on which the appellant attacked the judgment of the High Court was that, in reversing the finding of the Additional District Judge on the question of bona fide requirement of the Lohia Bazar shop by the respondent, the High Court exceeded its jurisdiction in second appeal.

Nor companyld this finding of fact-be said to be arbitrary, unreasonable, or perverse so as to merit interference by the High Court in second appeal. There can, therefore, be numberdoubt that the High Court in reversing the decision of the Additional District Judge and passing a decree for eviction against the appellant.

Nor companyld this finding of fact-be said to be arbitrary, unreasonable, or perverse so as to merit interference by the High Court in second appeal.
